title: Soul
summary: Joe Gardner is a middle-school band teacher who gets the chance of a lifetime to play at the best jazz club in town. But one small misstep takes him from the streets of New York City to The Great Before – a fantastical place where new souls get their personalities, quirks and interests before they go to Earth. Determined to return to hisJoe Gardner is a middle-school band teacher who gets the chance of a lifetime to play at the best jazz club in town. But one small misstep takes him from the streets of New York City to The Great Before – a fantastical place where new souls get their personalities, quirks and interests before they go to Earth. Determined to return to his life, Joe teams up with a precocious soul, 22, who has never understood the appeal of the human experience. As Joe desperately tries to show 22 what’s great about living, he may just discover the answers to some of life’s most important questions.… Expand
critic_reviews: Great animation can communicate wildly complex ideas with head-spinning clarity and wit, as Docter capably proved with Inside Out – a film which staged the interplay of emotions in an 11-year-old’s head like a vintage sitcom. If anything, Soul pushes this capacity for revelation even further: there are moments of true Blakean mystery and wonder here, expressed with a crispness that feels like a lightbulb snapping on above your head.

Here is a strikingly beautiful, bold, funny, heart-tugging otherworldly journey almost dizzying in its multi-leveled complexity, and yet containing the simplest and most enduring Capra-esque messages about how we don’t know what we’ve got until it’s gone, and how we should embrace every waking moment because it can all vanish in the blink of an eye.

It all blends together beautifully, a marriage of Pixar’s square, safe, feel-good sensibility with what could be described as the “real world” — and one that, much as “Inside Out” anthropomorphized the mind, will leave audiences young and old imagining their own souls as glowing idiosyncratic cartoon characters.

Pixar’s 23rd animated feature is an exercise in psychedelic existentialism that astonishingly increases in inventiveness as it goes along. Then, before you’re overwhelmed, it shifts into a lower gear, eventually arriving as a stirring and relatively simple meditation on what it means to be alive.
It’s a ravishing ode, too, to gestures, touches, smiles, and pithy, pointless conversations; in Soul the tiny human interactions that we so often brush over come under the magnifying glass.
It’s a deeply sweet, happy, gentle film.
Moving ever-onward from the sequels years, Pixar gets right back in the zone with Soul. Deep, witty, and fast on its jazz-loving feet, it doesn’t miss a beat.
Visually glorious, frequently very funny and genuinely profound, this is a picture which cries out to be seen on the big screen.

This densely packed, exquisitely executed and just a teensy bit batshit film is peak Pixar. It's a vintage mix of the company's intricate storytelling, complex emotional intelligence, technical prowess and cerebral whimsy on dexamethasone.

Pixar’s first feature with a predominantly Black cast and a Black lead actor (the superb Jamie Foxx) contemplates the origins of jazz and the meaning of life and death. Don't fret the metaphysics, kids, It's the year's peak achievement in animation.

Like the best moments in Up or Wall-E or Inside Out, the alchemy of Soul's final scenes find Pixar at its most stirring and enduring, a marshmallow puff of surreal whimsy that somehow lightly touches the profound.

Soul feels like the best Pixar movies used to feel — deeply humanistic, with both silly, kid-friendly humor and a sincere solemnity that feels entirely adult. Docter and Powers weaponize all of this in a story that literally and directly questions the meaning of life.
Soul likes jazz very much. That’s a rare certainty in this ambitious film, which attempts to contemplate nothing less than the root of all human experience on this planet.
Like some of the best jazz compositions, it uses a traditional framework to veer off in many unexpected directions, so that even the inevitable end point feels just right.
Soul stuffs its playful optimism into a simple message and delivers it with colorful, endearing beauty.

Credit Pixar veteran Pete Docter ("Up" and "Inside Out") and co-director Kemp Powers (the writer of the play and upcoming movie "One Night in Miami") with an addition to Pixar's library worthy of its classics.
It’s a small, delicate movie that doesn’t hit every note perfectly, but its combination of skill, feeling and inspiration is summed up in the title.

Soul wasn’t made for a world that’s just gone through the nightmares of 2020, but coming out at the end of this harrowing year, it couldn’t feel more poignant. It’s funny, and it’s imaginative, but it’s also just very, very real.

I think Soul will become a classic, but we must be patient too, because this stretch of the film is mostly illustrated notions, heavier on explanation than action. It’s very pretty—Klee-like figures and lots of pastel translucency—but not, perhaps inevitably, all that lively.

Soul asks its audience to examine what in life truly is important. You never know what your spark might be, until suddenly you do. And it might not be what you think. Turns out you may have had it all along.

At times, Soul is as heavy as it sounds, and invites all sorts of contemplation from viewers about our purpose on this planet, and whatever (and wherever) comes afterwards. At other times, it is uproariously funny, particularly after Joe and 22’s story takes a very unexpected turn in its second half. In typical Pixar fashion, it’s also visually stunning.
Soul turns out to be not an exploration of the afterlife but a wondrous whirligig of daily life.
Soul is messy, maudlin, funny, ridiculous, and poignant. In other words, it has soul.
Soul amounts to more than technical wizardry and intelligent dialogue. Why artists keep pounding the pavement despite never finding commercial success is a meaty topic.

Without becoming doctrinaire or espousing a particular religious ideology, Soul offers insight into the concept of death and the potential of an afterlife. It does this while maintaining a light tone and avoiding many of the obvious pitfalls that could accompany addressing such subject matter.
A holiday gift, it’s bringing some much-needed light to these dark days.

Soul is dealing with themes that may even be beyond its grasp. The idea of creative passions becoming a reason for living has been a recurring thread through most Pixar films, but Soul attempts to dig deeper. And while it may not find one perfect discernible answer, it’s a search that feels inherently…soulful.

If you’ve seen enough of the studio’s movies, even something this full of imagination suffers from some predictability. There is a period in Soul, where, in spite of the lovely creativity and goofy story-telling, it lags and feels a bit listless, before bouncing back.
The originality of vision remains strong with Pete Docter and his cohorts. But beyond strange new concepts, they need to dig deeper for more truly unexpected characters.
The visuals are as wildly original as the script, which was co-written by Docter, Kemp Powers, and Mike Jones.

It’s whimsical and bold and also easier to admire in the abstract than to get deeply emotionally invested in, though it features a late-breaking burst of beauty that will soften the hardest of hearts.
It’s a visually sumptuous riot of ideas, pitched somewhere between a playful musical, a divine comedy and a metaphysical drama.

The more you think about it, the more of a muddle Soul seems to be. But what a gorgeous muddle it is. It may not be wholly satisfying, but it is exhilarating in its ambition, superbly animated, and brimming with affection for its characters and their milieu.

The title, with its built-in weightiness ... well, it’s a tall order, one this latest Pixar animated feature falls just short of. The dominant mood here is not so much soulful as spirited, which is still better than most – and a most welcome gift.
Soul is a jazzy and profound riff on humanity and the hereafter, an entertaining, exuberant effort about our existence with comedic shenanigans, deep thoughts and wondrous imagination.

The beauty of Soul is that, just as animation is finding more being demanded of it, Pixar is answering that demand. It is making the case for animation as an ideal vehicle for exploring the grand, the general, the universal.
Despite some distraction and not quite enough music, Soul manages to tap into deep emotion as its characters explore the limits of mortality and what it means to be passionate about life.
There is a mesmerizing quality to the movie.

"Cars" and its various derivatives aside, Pixar has never released a flat-out bad film. And this is a good one: pleasant and clever, with a generous heart, committed voice acting, and some of the kookiest images in Pixar history.
It’s overflowing, like a bright portal into a new reality, with gorgeous details. So what if they don’t quite add up to a deeper whole?

It’s comical, but not really a comedy, spiritual without being all that deep. But as it grapples with what drives a creative person, paints the “after life” and “before life” eternity in Picasso-with-a-light-pen strokes and questions what makes life worth living, it can be quite touching.

There are many elaborate lessons on life and how to live it in Soul, though its best may ironically be its simplest: Look. Listen. Learn. Enjoy. You may not turn the film off with an answer to what a soul is. But you may find yourself wondering if you’re forgetting to occasionally connect with your own.
The lingering lesson of Soul, a lovely, imperfect movie about life’s lovely imperfections, is that every moment is worth living to the fullest, this one very much included.

Like every Pixar movie, it’s entertaining, sharp, and visually inventive. But it lacks the thunderbolts of creativity that make the company’s best philosophical inquiries so electrifying. It never quite finds its spark.
While Soul offers food for thought and has heart, it’s never quite as funny, engrossing, or emotionally rewarding as Pixar’s best.

Soul is perhaps the most existentially ambitious film ever attempted by Disney and yet it pops with colorful visuals and gentle wisdom while the story clips along despite the dizzying height of the concept. Only in the final stages do the knots of plot complexity get the better of the characters, but audiences will have been well won over by then.

Just as a movie skewed toward kids will bore adults, Soul will bore children, and it did mine. I love jazz, but I don’t think my child will add it to her Spotify playlist. In the end, Soul told a good, insightful story but was too much of a departure from the norm.

This dazzling, if ultimately frustrating, movie seems to pick up where the far superior “Inside Out” ended, leaving behind the inner workings of young people’s emotional lives for an exploration of metaphysical realms that are fuzzier, more speculative and, to put it bluntly, not nearly as involving.

While most Pixar films pride themselves on presenting rich, fantastical responses to real-world wonderings, Soul keeps conjuring up visions that don’t correspond precisely enough to anything in the real world.

If anything, Soul is guilty of over-ambition. The wizardry and wit is there, but it lacks Pixar’s usual deftness in making complex themes sing for youngsters. Mixing heart and existential angst, it’ll connect more with Joe’s generation than little ones. It’s smart and, yes, soulful but it never quite takes flight.

Overall, the movie is so ambitious—so intent on reminding us, every minute, that it really is a work of Big Ideas—that it ends up subverting its own charms. The Pixar masterminds often seem to think complicated is better, or at least just deeper. But to paraphrase Thelonious Monk, they’ve been making the wrong mistakes.
It’s a movie with the sort of resonance, thoughtfulness and universality that audiences of all descriptions will enjoy — and, more importantly, connect with.

What lets the film down somewhat is an issue that has dogged much of the studio’s recent middling efforts, namely an inert narrative and a wishy-washy message that ultimately doesn’t have the courage of its own convictions.
Soul isn't Pixar's finest or most resonant film, but its beautiful animation and soundtrack, paired with fun characters make for an enjoyable watch.
While not quite offering the emotional gut-punch it promises, its many ideas never completely cohering, Soul is nevertheless a gorgeous and tender existential trip. It’s full of surprises.

reviews.content: Amazing movie, I laughed , I cried, I got inspired. Make sure you have no distractions around you when you watch, turn the music up and let in to the story. WOW

This is probably the best Pixar film I’ve personally seen in a long time. Foxx’s performance was great and the jazz music is volumetric and nicely composed. The way Pixar addressed the narrative on the concept of one’s soul and the meaning ofThis is probably the best Pixar film I’ve personally seen in a long time. Foxx’s performance was great and the jazz music is volumetric and nicely composed. The way Pixar addressed the narrative on the concept of one’s soul and the meaning of life was both beautiful and interesting. Soul is a funny and heartwarming film and I highly recommend it.

*Closer to a 6.8/10.Visually perfect and thematically interesting but lacking that final polish. The notable lack of sound design gives the movie an awkward feel, understandable since it probably had to be done in quarantine but a problem*Closer to a 6.8/10.Visually perfect and thematically interesting but lacking that final polish. The notable lack of sound design gives the movie an awkward feel, understandable since it probably had to be done in quarantine but a problem none the less. There is also a lot I feel hurts the overall narrative of the film, most notably a scene early on that calls into question the ticking clock element of the story.A lot of fun none the less and I expect that I will get more out of it upon a rewatch.

This review contains spoilers, click expand to view.
        
This is a really great Pixar movie. I just wanna start off with that. It has breathtaking visuals, amazing music, and a great cast. Richard Ayoade keeps on being one of the best actors no one seems to recognize. The visual ideas are really inventive and interesting, "The zone" being one of the most creative things I have seen in a film. The montage towards the end of the film made me cry, and is peak Pixar. Pretty much every scene spent in the spirit realm is really great. The scenes on earth is more of a problem. They have a bit of a whiplash effect, after the creativity on display in the spirit realm. Another problem is the weird, essentially tangential part where the protagonist is turned into a cat. I really appreciate that 22 got to be a human, but couldn't she just discover the wonders of the world as a cat? Anyway, I really liked this movie, despite its mistakes. It isn't very funny, which is a bit of a sad trend with modern Pixar, but it is still pretty great. It reminds me of the glory days of pixar, of Ratatouille and Wall-e and Up. I really hope this might usher in other films like that. And also that they stop making movies like Onward.

The movie is basically inside out but a little bit more mature, with an even more interesting concept, better looking animation and some very relatable characters, Pixar is really back after this movie, and I can't wait to see what other ideas they have in the works.
A film full of emotion and heart. Great to watch, easy to follow. A truly amazing film for all ages.
Una película visualmente muy hermosas ,con música hermosa que demuestra de lo que es capaz Pixar con una historia envolvente y profunda que pone a pensar a uno acerca de una cosa...la vida

This film is so powerful! Even if it might be seen as a work that follows the path already took by inside out in 2015 it works very well. So hilarious during the first part but extremely deep in the final one.I might be exaggerated but iThis film is so powerful! Even if it might be seen as a work that follows the path already took by inside out in 2015 it works very well. So hilarious during the first part but extremely deep in the final one.I might be exaggerated but i consider this as an hymn to life and research of good in everything (which is not a bad thing according to this strange period), such a strong message.

I was really looking forward to this but I found the story lacking in both depth and logic. Visually lush, musically fantastic but it cannot hide a story that lacks originality, and a movie that tries way to hard to be charming.
This was not a good film. At times the plot felt empty, boring and lazy. This would be a great film for maybe older people.
Something lacks, but overall it's pretty fun.  Music is the best part, the animation amazing as always, but the story... well, it is great but could be better.

This movie captivated me quickly, but then left me a bit confused at parts. Not because anything was too ambitious or deep, it was more how disjointed the story seemed to be between the living world and spirit world. I don't want to ruinThis movie captivated me quickly, but then left me a bit confused at parts. Not because anything was too ambitious or deep, it was more how disjointed the story seemed to be between the living world and spirit world. I don't want to ruin anything but there are things that happen that flat out made zero sense and had my head scratching, especially in the last quarter of the movie. Also when the cat thing happened I was kinda like....I guess that has to be for the children because that route made way less sense to me than a fusion situation, where they were BOTH operating. It's one of those you have to just accept it's a fictional movie kind of deals.I really enjoyed most of the characters a lot. Terry was my biggest gripe character-wise. I get you aren't supposed to like him and he's arguably the only antagonist if there is one, but he was just a means to an end obviously. I just felt like there was a struggle to connect the two realms to further the story in the writers room. There was a lot of hurrying things along near the end.Overall a good movie that conveys a message about how our desire to seek purpose (and how those purposes can become obsessions) can take away from really "living" life. Just missed the mark a bit in the writers room.
Didactical, strong and beautifully animated; Soul is one of the best movies Pixar has ever made.

'Soul' is a dazzling movie. An adult will think about his life after watching it, and a kid will definitely feel attracted by the clever designs. The music, the animation, and the story are top-notch. The ending is a little too Disney, but,'Soul' is a dazzling movie. An adult will think about his life after watching it, and a kid will definitely feel attracted by the clever designs. The music, the animation, and the story are top-notch. The ending is a little too Disney, but, well, what matters is the spectacular trip Pixar has taken us this time.
Pretty good movie and hits home for teachers, musicians, artists, etc. Also did a lot better job than I expected with incorporating death in a children's movie than others.

This is difficult to rate. As an overall movie it's pretty good with deep meaning of life searching subject matter. Problem is it's pixar so if you sit the kids down expecting Frozen or the like they're going to be bored out of their minds.This is difficult to rate. As an overall movie it's pretty good with deep meaning of life searching subject matter. Problem is it's pixar so if you sit the kids down expecting Frozen or the like they're going to be bored out of their minds. This is drama with a capital D so maybe watch it before you think younger kids will enjoy it. Mine didn't. Not from a lack of quality but simply because it's just not a kids movie.Given that I have to wonder why they would even put it in pixar's hands instead of just making it live action. The subject matter is majorly adult but the visuals are very kids movie. I didn't hate it but was very dissatisfied when I was looking for a family movie that made everyone happy.

Really disappointed after such great reviews. There is a fantastic idea at the heart of this movie but it isn’t fully realised in a satisfactory way. Emotionally disjointed and seemingly confused by it’s own existential rules, it misses theReally disappointed after such great reviews. There is a fantastic idea at the heart of this movie but it isn’t fully realised in a satisfactory way. Emotionally disjointed and seemingly confused by it’s own existential rules, it misses the opportunity to match the ghosts of Pixar’s past. If the present critics say it does, then I fear for what is yet to come.

Disney and Pixar have struck gold with this animated feature about a struggling musician that finds the secret of life through a literal out-of-body experience. When I first saw the trailer for this movie, I wasn't blown away but afterDisney and Pixar have struck gold with this animated feature about a struggling musician that finds the secret of life through a literal out-of-body experience. When I first saw the trailer for this movie, I wasn't blown away but after watching it I must say it is not at all what I expected but that is a good thing. Soul is a film that does a lot of things right. It's main character is interesting and gets a decent amount of character development that helps audiences connect with him. The animation is stunning, the supporting cast is superb and the story is deeper than I could have imagined. I love stories that have a purpose and leave its viewers with a lasting effect long after the credits roll and this film certainly accomplishes that. Soul might not be a kids film but it is one of the best animated films of the year by a long shot.
Amazing movie. REALLY good visuals, very high quality, and music is amazing. Cast is great, too.

Some people have told me: ''Pixar never disappoints''.And I don't know about them, but for me they have, but Pixar has also produced superb classics in animation.Fortunately Soul will fall into that category.

Soul takes a similar approachSome people have told me: ''Pixar never disappoints''.And I don't know about them, but for me they have, but Pixar has also produced superb classics in animation.Fortunately Soul will fall into that category.Soul takes a similar approach to what the studio did on Inside Out, but let's say that here it takes you to the origin source.Everything is a metaphor of course, but the intuitive and captivating is what elevates this story.It could hardly be classified as a kid's film, because although they will be able to enjoy it of course, what makes this film special can only be appreciated by a more mature audience.A huge pity the film didn't get a theater release, because I would've loved to have seen it on the big screen, but that's water under the bridge, the film has been released worldwide now, and it's a wonderful adventure that I can recommend to everyone.

This is a really good movie! The art design and  the animation style are very nice to look at and keep your eyes engaged. The storyline is very thought provoking and the writing is top notch. The voice acting is good all around and you canThis is a really good movie! The art design and  the animation style are very nice to look at and keep your eyes engaged. The storyline is very thought provoking and the writing is top notch. The voice acting is good all around and you can really feel the emotion the actors are trying to convey. All around great movie and I highly recommend watching it!

An amazing Pixar movie for these hard times. Thoroughly enjoyed the whole movie. Animation is fantastic and so beautifully shot. The message in this film is so amazing and inspiring one of Pixar's best in years. May be harder for kids toAn amazing Pixar movie for these hard times. Thoroughly enjoyed the whole movie. Animation is fantastic and so beautifully shot. The message in this film is so amazing and inspiring one of Pixar's best in years. May be harder for kids to follow though. A great watch and one of the best movies of the year.

Desde que se mostraron los trailers ya sabia que esta película me encantaría. Da un gran mensaje y nos hace replantearnos muchas cosas de la vida. Los personajes son muy carismáticos y la animación es de lo mejor que he visto, pero si hablo de las cosas que no me gustaron, siento que la película rompe con la seriedad que transmite en algunas situaciones de comedia como cuando Joe se convierte en el gato, se siente como la parte mas débil de la película. Una película animada que toca tantos temas complejos y serios necesita equilibrar mucho mas su comedia y que se note menos forzada. Y después esta el tema de que siento que no explotan el mundo de fantasía que propone. Se menciona el gran despues, el infierno y el gran antes, pero creo que le falto un poquito mas de desarrollo. En su lugar, la película trata de explorar mas la vida de Joe.En mi opinión, no es una de las mejores películas animadas que he visto de todos los tiempos, pero definitivamente es una de las mejores que he visto en los últimos años. Muy recomendada, aunque los niños puede ser que no la entiendan del todo, siendo mas enfocada a los adultos por su complejidad.

Exciting from start to finish. Graphically perfect, Pixar's "Soul" innovates and takes audiences into a captivating and well-crafted story. It is worth mentioning the sound editing and soundtrack.  In my perception, the film comes strongly toExciting from start to finish. Graphically perfect, Pixar's "Soul" innovates and takes audiences into a captivating and well-crafted story. It is worth mentioning the sound editing and soundtrack.  In my perception, the film comes strongly to the dispute for "Best film" at the Oscar 2021.
Que bela surpresa! Se existe um filme capaz de quebrar o estigma de que animações são apenas para crianças, esse é certamente a melhor opção. Ele vai literalmente tocar a sua alma.

For me, Soul is the best movie of 2020. I didn’t expect to love this film so much but here I am. Very touching story, great characters and magnificent animation production.A MUST SEEN MOVIE FOR EVERYONE.
One of my favorite movies of all time. A masterpiece in every sense of the word.

Initial Thoughts:“Soul” is one of the must see films of the year. Why? Because it has a well thought out plot that is thought provoking, and at moments in time, emotionally heartening. This film is all it claims to be and more by not justInitial Thoughts:“Soul” is one of the must see films of the year. Why? Because it has a well thought out plot that is thought provoking, and at moments in time, emotionally heartening. This film is all it claims to be and more by not just skimming the surface of what most of us think in our day-to-day lives. It reaches much further into our souls. It had me thinking who I would like to be and what I could be. Although I didn’t find the answer in 2-hours it had me wondering, what is THE spark that makes me, me?Visually, this film is spectacular. At times I would forget that it was an animated film, but this aspect had me more invested into the incredible story. I think each individual who watches this film will have a different take and level of emotional response. Speaking for myself. At the end of the day I didn’t feel the emotional heartstrings being tugged at, but I honestly felt like my soul had been moved to want more and to be better.The last takeaway to this film is head up. Take each day for what it is and live it to your fullest because you may never get the opportunity for a do over or second chance. Be kind to yourself and those around you, as it may trodden them in such a way that they lose hope or faith in who they are and who they are meant to be.Overall:Honestly, this is a must see film before the year is up. It’s visually stunning, thought provoking, and emotionally driven. Admittedly, I did have my doubts and thought this film would fall short of my expectations, which was 10/10, but instead it met them, which was a 10/10.Enjoy the show!

A very heart warming movie, which constantly reminds you of that life is a blessing, even when it doesn't go as we planned. Remember how 'Indide Out' talked about your feelings' feelings? This one talks about your soul's feelings. Soul movie review out

Most children’s films have underlying messages or themes that teach important lessons to them without them knowing it, yet no movie has as important a message as Soul’s. This films message is simple, but complicated: live life to the fullest.Most children’s films have underlying messages or themes that teach important lessons to them without them knowing it, yet no movie has as important a message as Soul’s. This films message is simple, but complicated: live life to the fullest. Jamie Fox’s character goes through an emotional journey to not be told, but shown his purpose, all the while he unknowingly shows another theirs. If you have not seen this film, but have Disney+, it is a must-watch, and will be remembered alongside Pixar’s greatest.Alongside the the story, the animation is top-notch, which is as to be expected from Pixar, and the performances from the cast are all sublime.Soul once again raises the bar for what Pixar can do through animation and I highly anticipate their next project.

I would place SOUL among the first rank of Pixar animations, which means among the first rank of animations ever made. Of course, it's visually amazing, but its storytelling couldn't aim any higher. It's about New York, the Black AmericanI would place SOUL among the first rank of Pixar animations, which means among the first rank of animations ever made. Of course, it's visually amazing, but its storytelling couldn't aim any higher. It's about New York, the Black American experience, jazz, teaching -- and the meaning of existence. And unlike practically any other movie about jazz, the music is first-rate. (John Baptiste, Questlove, and Herbie Hancock were among the performers and consultants.) My only question is — what will young children get out of this? It's hugely entertaining, but like the director's INSIDE OUT, it tackles knotty philosophical questions and will inspire a mountain of scholarly papers.

Visually compelling scenes on Earth interspersed with graphic **** of both the visual and philosophical kinds - when exploring the befores and afters of life on Earth. The movie introduces a lot of threads and leaves many of them untied atVisually compelling scenes on Earth interspersed with graphic **** of both the visual and philosophical kinds - when exploring the befores and afters of life on Earth. The movie introduces a lot of threads and leaves many of them untied at the end and many that are tied are tied off in a “wrong” and unsatisfying way. And what about Lisa? She is Chekov’s gun.
Terrible.  Dragged.  Boring.  Hard to follow.  8 year old, 15 year old and 2 adults couldn't get through it.  Great cast, bad movie.

It is the movie "Heaven Can Wait" (1943 and 1978). Not sure why the people scenes are animated. The "uncanny valley" problem is huge, it pulls you out of the movie, over and over again. It really is a live-action & animated movie. It isn'tIt is the movie "Heaven Can Wait" (1943 and 1978). Not sure why the people scenes are animated. The "uncanny valley" problem is huge, it pulls you out of the movie, over and over again. It really is a live-action & animated movie. It isn't "The Incredibles" where the character's powers and stylization make sense. They tried to make it for all audiences and in the end, it isn't made for anyone. It is not for little kids because the theme is adult philosophical ideas and it is not for adults because the pacing and visuals are for kids. If you like "Inside Out" this will work for you, if you were just OK with "Inside Out" then make sure you have your fast forward button handy.

Tried watching this with my kids. They were not hooked at any point. The character and themes are not targeted at kids at all. I guess Pixar learnt that most of it's audience were adults anyway, so they forget what made them movies specialTried watching this with my kids. They were not hooked at any point. The character and themes are not targeted at kids at all. I guess Pixar learnt that most of it's audience were adults anyway, so they forget what made them movies special for youngsters. Sure, the plot is interesting and very well acted and animated. Just make sure you watch it with the right audience, kids will be bored.

One of the best movie I have ever seen in years.After watching this movie it motivates and hypes up me to work on the thing I loved and care about. I have never felt like that after watching a movie. One of the best movie to watch thisOne of the best movie I have ever seen in years.After watching this movie it motivates and hypes up me to work on the thing I loved and care about. I have never felt like that after watching a movie. One of the best movie to watch this holiday season.

Sad but also very wholesome at the same time. Wouldn’t rank it among my favorite but still a excellent Christmas movie way better than that other movie I watched today about some girl superhero. This was much better movie to enjoy this holiday!
Wow! A beautiful and thoughtful story that takes you on a ride and challenge you to think about the message. Feels like the first Pixar film made for adults, one of the best movies this year.
Soul is yet another Pixar masterpiece. Easily the best animated movie since Coco, and the definitive animated movie of 2020.

A moving, charming, and delightful palate cleanser, Soul not only manages to be Pixar’s coolest looking film (and a fantastically New York film for that matter) but it also delivers a heartwarming message about the simple beauty of living -A moving, charming, and delightful palate cleanser, Soul not only manages to be Pixar’s coolest looking film (and a fantastically New York film for that matter) but it also delivers a heartwarming message about the simple beauty of living - and what a pure gift life is. Touching on subjects such as passion and mental health, the film’s heavy themes are balanced with Pixar’s signature sharp-witted humor, a soft and gorgeous soundtrack, and a pleasing color scheme during the astral sequences. It’s an absolute triumph - it will bring tears to your eyes and a sense of profound gratitude.

The “Miro” world was the least interesting dimension,  It felt better in the honest human character moments. As ever though an exquisitely crafted movie with a good heart.

Full of emotion, humor, power, and (well) soul, Disney/Pixar's "Soul" is easily the best film of 2020. As one of the most visually-captivating animated films combined with an even more provoking narrative, Soul presents itself with hardlyFull of emotion, humor, power, and (well) soul, Disney/Pixar's "Soul" is easily the best film of 2020. As one of the most visually-captivating animated films combined with an even more provoking narrative, Soul presents itself with hardly anything to dislike about it. From start to end, you'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll want to watch it again and again, all while watching gorgeous, jaw-dropping visuals. Released at a time where social equity matters more than ever in the world, this is certainly the movie to watch this holiday season and one whose legacy will live on for years to come.

I'm not saying people should NOT "enjoy every little things" but the pandering message is NOT what this world needs RIGHT NOW. While the underprivileged are enjoying their little slice of street corner pizza, the rich are savoring their $400I'm not saying people should NOT "enjoy every little things" but the pandering message is NOT what this world needs RIGHT NOW. While the underprivileged are enjoying their little slice of street corner pizza, the rich are savoring their $400 caviar in a pen-house on 40th floor; while the underprivileged are feeling the ocean sweeping over their feet on a disgusting public beach, the rich are sailing on a yacht more expensive than their entire home. Do you see it now? And this movie is telling the poor to just "watch the leaf fall" while their life-hood is quietly and slowly stolen away from them. This is so f*&k up.We are NOT living in a society where equal effort warrants equal returns and the disparity of wealth is so staggering that fundamental systematic change is required immediately. This is NOT a time to ask people to "enjoy the little things", this is a time to ask people to make a difference, regardless what your role is in this society.This is such a feel-good movie for lower-middle-class white people when the heroes of the movie - the black/brown communities are actually trying to make their ends meet every, single, day. So f*&k Pete Doctor and Pixar, for trying to teach black people how to live their lives and find their purpose.

This review contains spoilers, click expand to view.
        
Soul is an original movie from Pixar proving that the studio isn't yet down crafting stories that tackle ambitious themes. In this movie we see Joe Gardner, voiced by the talented Jamie Foxx, who thinks that he is living a meaningless life and that if he was just able to get his big break his life will finally have purpose. Right after getting his chance do play at a Jazz club with other talented musicians that he thinks will give his life meaning he dies and in trying to return to his life he ends up with an unborn soul named 22, who for thousands of years has been avoiding living. While trying to get Joe back into his body, 22 gets trapped inside of his fleshy prison, while Joe is locked in the form of a cat. Through this new perspective on life, 22 learns to put aside all of her preconceived notions about life on Earth and Joe comes to realization that it's the little things, not your passion, that make life meaningful. We realize that 22 has been avoiding life and is tries to create a disrespectful persona just to disguise her own insecurities with everyone telling her that her life isn't one worth living and through the mentor-ship of Joe she realizes that she is worth it and that life is worth cherishing.

I know a lot of people had their doubts when first seeing the promotional material and trailers for this Movie. From what I've seen, people have thought that the "Soul" part of the movie would just be there to cater to younger audiences.I know a lot of people had their doubts when first seeing the promotional material and trailers for this Movie. From what I've seen, people have thought that the "Soul" part of the movie would just be there to cater to younger audiences. However, after watching the film, I think people will realize that that's not the case. The way the soul world is intertwined with the real world can be a bit confusing at times, but is executed beautifully overall. This film is probably  the most mature-themed Pixar movie I've seen. The visuals are absolutely stunning, and the storytelling is executed very well. This is probably one of the few movies that has hit close to home with me, and I can see it doing the same with others. I love to see that Pixar is constantly innovating and finding new ways to speak to the audience personally. I understand if some might not like the theme because of it's complicated nature, and it's more mature target audience, and that's okay. While there are a few shortcomings that I can't quite put my finger on currently, I think this movie has one of the most powerful messages, and definitely had an impact on me.

I am very disappointed by this movie which took a direction that was completely unnecessary. The movie looks beautiful, and I thought the first minutes of it were brilliant, but for whatever reason Pixar decided to turn it into an even moreI am very disappointed by this movie which took a direction that was completely unnecessary. The movie looks beautiful, and I thought the first minutes of it were brilliant, but for whatever reason Pixar decided to turn it into an even more conceptual version of Inside Out that's very tough to understand for kids. It's a shame because I think the message of the film is beautiful, but it would have meant much more if it was told using the real world and the human characters they're presenting to you instead of surreal concepts. All these concepts they introduce in this movie are there just to try the same thing Inside Out already tried and we already saw. And it just doesn't work for me.

My kids preferred Cars. I'm not sure why Pixar thought making a film for kids about midlife crisis, existentialism and general meaning of life, with jazz and no child characters was a good idea.  Each of our boys (8,6,2) drifted off to playMy kids preferred Cars. I'm not sure why Pixar thought making a film for kids about midlife crisis, existentialism and general meaning of life, with jazz and no child characters was a good idea.  Each of our boys (8,6,2) drifted off to play with Lego etc, and they NEVER do that. There seemed to be very little to which they could relate. There are almost no children in the film, my kids aren't big on jazz, and it wasn't very colourful for large parts. There was a (quite sensible) talking cat and a bit where characters poop whole slices of pizza. They liked those bits.  IMO Disney can't hold a flame to Miyazaki when it comes to the mystical and this film really proved the point.  But compared to other Pixar offerings it doesn't have the charm of Up or the cleverness of Inside Out. But Soul's big failing is it just isn't very much fun.
What a disappointment! A long winding boring story that had very few redeeming moments of joy.  Save your time and re-watch one of classic Pixar movies instead.

Amazing visuals, snappy dialogue, interesting characters, lacking story, deplorable protagonist, and an ending that doesn't provide closure. I'd say I barely enjoyed watching it and will probably not see it another time. This movie honestly feels like it's trying to imitate Pixar's Inside Out, but does so with disingenuous material and does it poorly.We follow our main guy Joe along his life being obsessed with music and finally getting the gig he wants only to fall into a sewer and die. From there we get to see the Great Beyond and the Great Before; terms that become problematic when talking about any actual afterlife that the movie makes neatly side step by saying that's all in the beyond.Joe is able to avoid the Beyond (only to put a time limit on his actions and to trick him into thinking he's special) and escapes to the Before, where he proceeds to get back to his body even at the cost of stealing other's lives. Joe constantly shows he's selfish and doesn't care about others and only changes after he destroys a life and only through Deus Machina fixes it.Combined with a lot of psych nonsense rhetoric, anti-christian hints, and naive view of life makes this movie feel like a way of tricking the next generation the way Disney did the previous: feelings are all that matter.
Movie is riddled with plot holes. I was really excited to see it, but was extremely let down.

The latest gem from Pixar, a man who dreams of becoming a jazz musician is nearly killed in an accident, resulting in an out-of-body experience as his soul takes a journey through a subconscious world where souls strive to find purpose andThe latest gem from Pixar, a man who dreams of becoming a jazz musician is nearly killed in an accident, resulting in an out-of-body experience as his soul takes a journey through a subconscious world where souls strive to find purpose and meaning in life. With the help of a lost and rebellious soul by his side, he must try to get back into his own body while also learning about the joys of living along the way. Pixar almost never fails to put a smile on my face, even with some of their lesser efforts in the past, and this one is no exception in the smiles department for me. However, it also turned out to be one of their most mature and ambitious efforts to date! Complete with beautiful and colorful visuals, a great voice cast led by Jamie Foxx, a touching and often times funny story, a universal theme for anybody to relate to, and even a mature and impressive musical score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, it's sure to be enjoyed by just about anybody and will hopefully even make you appreciate the little things in life more! There are some familiar-feeling story beats at times, but they're more than made up for through the gorgeous animation and storytelling that Pixar's become so beloved for over the years. Overall, it may not necessarily be one of Pixar's tear-jerker flicks, and while only feeling a little formulaic in a scene or two, the film's heartwarming and unique enough to stand out as one of Pixar's best recent triumphs to date!

Soul in my humble opinion is the most imaginative and philosophical movie Pixar has ever made. It delves into the meaning of life, the great Before and After, the purpose of our existence and the spark of our soul. The journey of selfSoul in my humble opinion is the most imaginative and philosophical movie Pixar has ever made. It delves into the meaning of life, the great Before and After, the purpose of our existence and the spark of our soul. The journey of self discovery is one we must all undertake, some sooner, some later, some never. All this is well addressed in Soul, in a very metaphysical way. Pixar animation just keeps getting better - reflections of lights on the glass panes of pictures, mottled rust on aging metro rail pillars, hazy sunlight filtered through autumn leaves. Just such a delight to watch this bustling realistic world of New York unfold. Soul is probably the most musically authentic of all Pixar movies, diving deep into Jazz and other genres. But at the end the message remains paramount - see the forest beyond the trees, see the ocean beyond the waters. Life isn’t one big moment, it’s lots of little moments, treasure them all.

The commentary makes clear how many story changes occurred andPretty terrific.  A treat for anyone into visual imagination.  Much better and less draggy 2nd act than Inside Out. The Redbox version I got had the director's commentary track.  The commentary makes clear how many story changes occurred and how the audience is to decide what Joe choses to do when he comes back to Earth.  Reincarnation is by no means the main theme here. Rather it ends in a very big Zen place John Lennon famously described as, Life is what happens to you while you are making other plans." Soul out performed my expectations by miles, I thought it looked good but never knew it would be near perfection. The animation was astounding, it was gorgeous and the character designs were stupendous and so original especially the designsSoul out performed my expectations by miles, I thought it looked good but never knew it would be near perfection. The animation was astounding, it was gorgeous and the character designs were stupendous and so original especially the designs of the souls, the Jerry's, and Terry. The writing was remarkable especially the story, it was beautiful, touching, deep, and shows us that no matter what we do the most important thing in life is to just be happy and that there is no right answer of how to live our lives just that to be happy with what we do with our lives. I loved how original the concept was for a Pixar and animated movie, it was outstanding. The music was exceptional, one of the best musical scores of all time. The voice acting was phenomenal especially from Tina Fey, Jamie Foxx, Rachel House, Alice Braga, Richard Ayode, Phylicia Rashad, and Angela Bassett. Soul is one of my top 5 favorite movies of 2020, my 2nd favorite animated movie of 2020, and one of my favorite movies of all time, definite A+.

Not really a childrens movie, a lot of it will go right over the top of kids heads and they wont fully understand it. It is a more adult surreal version of Inside Out. Some of the animation is beautiful and abstract concepts are lovinglyNot really a childrens movie, a lot of it will go right over the top of kids heads and they wont fully understand it. It is a more adult surreal version of Inside Out. Some of the animation is beautiful and abstract concepts are lovingly visualised, the whole movie has some excellent artwork. The Atmos soundtrack is also really well done, especially during the Beyond parts of the film. Overall I enjoyed it but it doesn't hit the heights of some of the other Pixar classics, I would say this is a good but not great film. At its heart the story has a pretty obvious, predicable and somewhat corny and preachy message.

A pleasant surprise considering the original trailer for this film made it look like Inside Out 2. This is a huge step up in quality from Pixar’s previous film Onward from last year. For reference, I gave Onward a 5/10. Soul has probably theA pleasant surprise considering the original trailer for this film made it look like Inside Out 2. This is a huge step up in quality from Pixar’s previous film Onward from last year. For reference, I gave Onward a 5/10. Soul has probably the most gorgeous animation in a Pixar film and I know saying that good animation in a Pixar film is like saying water is wet but I really wanted to highlight it here because it’s incredibly gorgeous. The way Pete Docter and the animators incorporate different colors and shots for both the spirit world and New York is beyond amazing. Some might be glad to know that this film doesn’t feel like Inside Out 2 like most were predicting. They only spend maybe 1/4 or 1/3 of the movie in the spirit world and I really enjoyed a lot of the metaphysical jokes they made and the art style of it. It distinguished itself from Inside Out by doing this. The story and themes here are captivating. We learn through Jamie Foxx’s character Joe that we need to slow down and not devout ourselves to only one idea or else we will get stuck in that pit never get out. There is also a lot about our purpose and what we should do with our life which is represented through Tina Fey’s character 22. It’s surprising at how mature these themes are even for a film that is geared towards a younger audience. I have to talk about the music too because it’s great. Scratch that, it’s incredible. It’s almost all jazz music and it fits the themes and tones of the film perfectly. You couldn’t ask for a better score than this. My issues with the film are with its ending and one performance; Graham Norton. I think Norton is a fine talk show host but it was distracting whenever he was on screen here. They probably should have cast somebody else because his performance was average at best compared to the great performances from Jamie Foxx and Tina Fey. The ending of this film is a little bit abrupt and a tad underwhelming. We get this absolutely incredible Jazz section with Joe reflecting on life before it takes us to a more normal ending and I kinda wish the film had been resolved in a better way. I still think the ending is good but it could have been better. If you enjoy Pixar movies or just animated movies in general then I would highly recommend this.
